My Teaching

  We are all learners, and we are all still learning.

Building inclusive teaching environments means respecting that each individual may have different learning styles and starting points.

Teaching can be understood as facilitating a continuous, lifelong active learning process.

This WI+RE Learning Narrative articulates my firsthand experience as a volunteer at a rural school in Tianshangping (天上平), located in Hubei Province (湖北), China. I was invited to be part of a special team of teachers and school administrators from the Wuhan Foreign Languages School (WFLS), a K-12 academy in central China.

  Learners can be teachers, and teachers can be learners.

Instruction can be a two-way street.

"By teaching you are taught." (Translated from the Japanese film, 日日是好日: Every Day Is a Good Day by Tatsushi Omori). This phrase embodies my view of teaching. The teachers who left the deepest impression on me have always exhibited an interest in learning from the ones they taught. A mutual investment in education and lifelong learning can go a very long way.

The film also advises us that: "Some things are quickly understood, and some things take time. The things easily understood need only be gone through once. But those other things, you come to understand only with time, little by little." Having the patience to work with learners at all stages can nurture understanding that continues to grow far beyond the classroom.

  The lesson planning process can be understood as iterative and self-reflective.

Throughout my teaching experience, I have found that the lion's share of the work falls under lesson planning.

Once learning objectives are set, lesson plans have been created, and templates for accompanying teaching materials developed, they are carried out in the classroom. Put to test in this crucial proving ground, teaching has actually become the "easiest" part of the entire process, relatively speaking.

Lastly, formative assessments in the lesson itself and throughout the term can help to promote self-reflection following the teaching experience. If an overlooked point or a particularly thoughtful question was brought up in class, I note these down and use them to modify my next lesson plan.

These iterative and self-reflective practices in turn teach me how to become a better teacher. Combined with collaboration and communication with colleagues & peers, teaching becomes an act of constant refinement and subtle adjustments that can make all the difference in the world of a learner just embarking on a new subject matter or set of research methods in an unfamiliar discipline (such as humanities or the social sciences).

  Teaching Aide for UCLA Global Classroom Program at Jinling High School (金陵中学) | Nanjing, China.

Fall 2019

20th Century American History (Hist XL 13C) | Professor Eric Altice

This course will examine United States history from approximately 1890 to 1990. Major themes include industrialization and its effects (urbanization, migration, etc), the emergence of the United States as a world power, the development of the Federal Government, Civil Rights, and political party alignment.

Sociology 1 (Soc XL 1) | Professor Justin Gelzhiser

Sociology is the systematic study of society. It is a broad field that covers a wide range of areas of human social life. Additionally, sociology analyzes social life on a wide variety of levels, from interactions between two individuals, to the structure of society as a whole, and even to the interactions between societies on a global scale.

The course will begin with a general introduction to sociology, including several major perspectives and research methods. From there, we will be looking at the interaction between individuals and society, some of the major institutions that shape society, and the power structures that impact social life.

Spring 2020

20th Century American History (Hist XL 13C) | Professor Eric Altice

This course will examine United States history from approximately 1890 to 1990. Major themes include industrialization and its effects (urbanization, migration, etc), the emergence of the United States as a world power, the development of the Federal Government, Civil Rights, and political party alignment.

Sociology 1 (Soc XL 1) | Professor Justin Gelzhiser

Sociology is the systematic study of society. It is a broad field that covers a wide range of areas of human social life. Additionally, sociology analyzes social life on a wide variety of levels, from interactions between two individuals, to the structure of society as a whole, and even to the interactions between societies on a global scale.

The course will begin with a general introduction to sociology, including several major perspectives and research methods. From there, we will be looking at the interaction between individuals and society, some of the major institutions that shape society, and the power structures that impact social life.

History of American Popular Culture (HIST XL 142D) | Professor Eric Altice

This course examines the development and impact of American Popular Culture, that is, forms of entertainment and artistic culture that resonate with a wide audience in the United States. While the title of the class indicates a focus on 20th Century Pop Culture, parts of the class will be spent examining material from the 19th Century as well, and also glance at contemporary, 21st Century pop culture at the end of the class.

Rather than focus on a specific time frame, the course will look at various themes, and seek to understand how these different themes relate to Pop Culture,and how Pop Culture in America relates to the specific environment of American society. Some of these issues, such as race and gender ideologies and discourses, clearly reach far back into the 19th Century (and beyond); others, such as the emergence of advertising as a cultural force, are more firmly located in the 20th Century.

Students in this course will learn about whatever era necessary to understand the topic at hand. Furthermore, understanding Pop Culture will require that they also develop a strong understanding of economic, demographic, political, and technological changes that influence the shape and content of Popular entertainment and media. Thus, the study of Pop Culture leads not only to a better understanding of media and the things individuals watch and listen to entertain themselves, but also to a deeper understanding of the United States more generally.
